text: How can a non-assigned string in Python have an address in memory?
Can someone explain this to me?
So I've been playing with the id() command in python and came across this:
This makes some sense to me except for one part: The string 'cat' has an address in memory before I assign it to a variable.
I probably just don't understand how memory addressing works but can someone explain this to me or at least tell me that I should read up on memory addressing?
So that is all well and good but this confused me further:
This struck me as weird because 'cat' is a string with an address of 5181152 but the new a has a different address.
So if there are two 'cat' strings in memory why aren't two addresses printed for id('cat')?
My last thought was that the concatenation had something to do with the change in address so I tried this:
I would have predicted the IDs to be the same but that was not the case.
